nodes.bodyText: This is a possibly backwards incompatible change, so make sure to add this to the release notes.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -205,22 +205,24 @@ public static double toUnixTimeFromTimestampWithTimeZone(@SqlType(StandardTypes.
     }
 
     @ScalarFunction("to_iso8601")
-    @SqlType("varchar(35)")
-    // YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmm+HH:MM is a standard notation, and it requires 29 characters.
-    // However extended notation with format ±(Y)+-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmm+HH:MM is also acceptable and as
-    // the maximum year represented by 64bits timestamp is ~584944387 it may require up to 35 characters.
+    @SqlType("varchar(29)")
+    // YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmm is a standard notation, and it requires 23 characters.
+    // However extended notation with format ±(Y)+-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmm is also acceptable and as
+    // the maximum year represented by 64bits timestamp is ~584944387 it may require up to 29 characters.

nodes.bodyText: It's a tighter result which is coercible to the previous type, so it shouldn't break any existing usages.

nodes.bodyText: What if I add 1000 milliseconds?
Yup, that's a bug. What I really need to do is truncate the result to the expected precision.
you might want a named function for this
Maybe add a named function from this
We should add this to the documentation

It's already documented. I guess it comes from MySQL's documentation:

.. [#f] Timestamp is truncated to milliseconds.
@Description("Formats the given timestamp by the given format")
Maybe add a utility for this
multiply exact?
Consider adding a special method that takes long and int.
s/WIT/WITH
We should decide on this before pushing
I'm leaning towards truncation. The math is much simpler than rounding, especially when dealing with negative epoch values. Thoughts?
maybe move the formula to a constant
Why not use the lookup table
Leftover from before I had that lookup table. I'll update
Did you mean to leave this in?  It seems like a good verification to have
No, leftover from some debugging I was doing.
make sure precision is positive?
I'm surprised you need this
Probably not needed. I copied from AbstractLongBlock when I had to split the implementation for short vs long.
Long + Int?
Good catch. That was not intended. I originally copied some methods from LongDecimalType and forgot to update.
maybe add a helper method for getLow and getHigh
verify fraction is not > 1_000_000?
Maybe add a comment here.  I expect we will use this flag for timestamp and time with and without TZ

I'm not sure how all clients work, but they might not expect the parametric timestamp in the returned type list of the results metadata. To address that you would change io.prestosql.server.protocol.Query#toClientTypeSignature

That's a good question. In client type signature, they appear as parameters in a separate structure. I wonder whether clients validate that there are no parameters for timestamp or just match on the name and ignore the parameters if they are present.
@electrum, any thoughts?
I added a check for capabilities in toClientTypeSignature.
Maybe add a constant for that.
We should add ZoneID to DateTimeZoneIndex
I already added it, but forgot to update this callsite
This doesn't return millis
update comment
Update comment
use static import?
should this be renamed to contain the word round
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -90,12 +101,12 @@ public static long scaleEpochMillisToMicros(long epochMillis)
 
     public static long epochMillisToMicros(long epochMillis, int picosOfMilli)

nodes.bodyText: same

Shouldn't the default implementation throw?
(otherwise "should" -> "can")
Yeah, "can" is more appropriate
Create an issue for these deprecations for someone to follow up

.matches suggests some "pattern matching", while here it's equality (disregaring orders)
any better name? returns?

Hmmm... that's a very narrow interpretation of "matches". That word means, generally, to "be equal to" or "be similar to". I think it conveys the intent closely enough: "the results of the current query match the results of the given query".
On the other hand, "returns" also suggests it returns that exact string value, so it's not necessarily a better choice.
don't you need up to 12?

nodes.bodyText: Yes, but that actually doesn't help anyway. Joda only supports parsing up to millisecond precision, so everything after that is lost. I changed the parser entirely to support up to nanosecond precision (what JDBC Timestamp allows).

Define how should be epochMicro = -4, picosOfMicro = 42 be interpreted

+package io.prestosql.spi.type;
+
+import java.util.Objects;
+
+public final class LongTimestamp
+{
+    private static final int PICOSECONDS_PER_MICROSECOND = 1_000_000;
+
+    private final long epochMicros;
+    private final int picosOfMicro; // number of picoSeconds of the microsecond corresponding to epochMicros

nodes.bodyText:
A particular reason for not using ZoneOffset.UTC here?
(we tend to use ZoneOffset.UTC predominantly)
No particular reason. They are equivalent, but I'll update it. It saves a lookup.
nit: Class 'LessThan' has only 'static' members, and lacks a 'private' constructor
I think that's too noisy. We end up with a bunch of dummy constructors for no reason. It's clear that these classes are not meant to be used or instantiated.
You can suppress this on top-level class level. Ignoreable IDE warning make it harder to notice the ones i shouldn't ignore.
nit: verify picosOfMicro is in appropriate range (primarily to catch negative values)
Good catch!

Actually, no, it doesn't matter. It turns out that the values are already pre-rounded to the expected precision by the time this object is constructed -- all the positions after the given precision will be 0. So the rounding in this method is unnecessary. I'll simplify it.
I'll also add validation or rounding in the various constructors.

This method is responsible for rounding (data is not pre-rounded) when the client does not support new capability.
For this cases at least please do add test cases. (precision=3, values: any)
(In the test you also have a comment why you are not testing certain cases, as they are not possible in real code.)

No, this method is not the one that's used for rendering to the client. It's the default toString implementation for SqlTimestamp. In any case, I simplified this whole thing a bit. I added a roundTo() method to SqlTimestamp and updated the protocol layer to use that instead and not deal with calling the formatting code directly. I added some tests (and found a minor bug along the way).

No, this method is not the one that's used for rendering to the client.

Perhaps i got mislead because we have similar (but not equal) formatTimestamp in SqlTimestamp and Timestamps.
What's the reason?
Visibility. SqlTimestamp is in the SPI, but Timestamps is not (and should not be -- it has too many low-level implementation methods)
